abstract.p: Letter by Peter Jones of Mothers Against Drunk Driving urges Congress to make .08 blood alcohol concentration national standard for drunken driving (S)

block.p: I strongly urge Congress to make .08 blood alcohol concentration the national standard for drunken driving (editorial, Sept. 18). Eighteen states and the District of Colombia have already enacted .08 laws, and a Gallup survey showed 72 percent of Americans support a national .08 standard. Nearly 25 percent of drivers involved each year in alcohol-related traffic deaths have blood alcohol concentrations below .10.

I strongly urge Congress to make .08 blood alcohol concentration the national standard for drunken driving (editorial, Sept. 18). Eighteen states and the District of Colombia have already enacted .08 laws, and a Gallup survey showed 72 percent of Americans support a national .08 standard. Nearly 25 percent of drivers involved each year in alcohol-related traffic deaths have blood alcohol concentrations below .10.
The driver in the crash that killed my son had a .08 concentration; he served no jail time and received five years' probation.

The alcohol and restaurant lobbies will argue interference with social drinking. Yet a 170-pound male would have to consume four drinks in an hour on an empty stomach before reaching .08, whereas a 137-pound woman would have to consume three drinks. That's hardly ''social drinking.''
PETER JONES Deer Park, N.Y., Sept. 18, 2000
The writer is president of the Long Island chapter of Mothers Against Drunk Driving.
